metadata.case_name: State of Punjab v. Sodhi Sukhdev Singh

facts.text: Respondent was a District and Sessions Judge in the erstwhile State of Pepsu.
Respondent removed from service on April 7, 1953, by order passed by the President of India who was in charge of administration of Pepsu.
Respondent made representation on May 18, 1955, against removal order.
Council of Ministers of Pepsu considered representation on September 28, 1955, after end of President's rule, expressed views in Resolution, invited advice of Public Service Commission.
Council considered representation again on March 8, 1956, after receiving PSC advice, views recorded in minutes.

Council considered representation finally on August 11, 1956, passed order: 'Reference his representation dated the 18th May, 1955, against the order of his removal from service the State Government have ordered that he may be re-employed on some suitable post.' Order communicated to respondent.
Respondent filed suit on May 5, 1958, against appellant for declaration that removal illegal, void, inoperative, and recovery of Rs. 62,700-6-0 as arrears of salary.
Appellant disputed claim on several grounds. Issues framed by trial judge on January 27, 1959.
Respondent filed application under O. 14 r. 4 and O. 11 r. 14 CPC for production of documents listed.
Trial court issued notice for production. Mr. E. N. Mangat Rai, Chief Secretary, filed affidavits claiming privilege under s. 123 Evidence Act for certain documents, giving reasons.
Trial court on August 27, 1959, upheld privilege for some documents.
Respondent filed revision in Punjab High Court under s. 115 CPC and Art. 227 Constitution (C.R. 596 of 1959). Initially before D.K. Mahajan J., referred to larger bench Dulat and Dua JJ.
High Court reversed trial court order for four documents, directed production.
Appellant applied for certificate under Art. 133, dismissed, obtained special leave from Supreme Court.
Documents in question: Original order by Pepsu Govt on Sept 28, 1955; on March 8/9, 1956; on Aug 11, 1956; PSC report.
Previous Civil Appeal No. 241 of 1955 (Dowager Lady Dinbai Dinshaw Petit v. Union of India and State of Bombay) raised same point, settled by compromise, interveners allowed.

legal_issues.text: Scope and effect of ss. 123 and 162 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872, regarding claim of privilege by head of department for unpublished official records relating to affairs of State.
Whether Court can inspect documents or enquire into injury to public interest, or determine if document relates to affairs of State.
Whether four specific documents relate to affairs of State and are privileged under s. 123.

petitioner_arguments.text: Ss. 123 and 162 incorporate English Crown privilege law as in 1872; head of department decides if document privileged class and if production injurious to public interest; Court has limited jurisdiction, cannot inspect or enquire into contents or injury.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: ss. 123, 162 Evidence Act; English cases: Home v. Lord F.C. Bentinck, Smith v. East India Co., Beatson v. Skene; Draft Art. 112 by Stephen

petitioner_arguments.text: Affidavits by Chief Secretary sufficient; documents relate to public business/affairs of State.
S. 162 does not apply to discovery/inspection stage under O.11 r.19 CPC; Court can inspect there.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: O.11 r.19(2) CPC; s.162 Evidence Act

respondent_arguments.text: Affairs of State narrowly construed to noxious documents only; Court determines character and if disclosure injurious.
Documents are cabinet minutes/orders/PSC report on representation, not affairs of State; no injury to public interest.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.123 Evidence Act; Governor-General v. H. Peer Mohd.

court_reasoning.text: S.123 prohibits evidence from unpublished official records relating to affairs of State without head's permission; justified by public interest overriding private; affairs of State include political/administrative matters affecting defence/security/relations, or documents impairing frank expression in public policy (notes/minutes).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Public interest paramount; no definition straitjacket.

court_reasoning.text: S.162 requires witness produce document, Court decides objection validity; cannot inspect if matters of State, but take other evidence. Court holds preliminary enquiry into whether relates to affairs of State; if yes, head decides production; cannot enquire into injury.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Harmonious construction: Court determines class, head decides injury.

court_reasoning.text: Privilege claimed by affidavit of Minister/Secretary, showing careful consideration, brief reasons especially for borderline docs; can call further affidavit/cross-examine.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not on litigation impact, only public injury.

court_reasoning.text: Documents are cabinet minutes/advice to Rajpramukh and PSC report; relate to affairs of State as proceedings/discussions; protected.
High Court erred in enquiring into injury and using narrow definition.

holdings.text: Court determines if document relates to affairs of State; if yes, head of department decides permission based on public injury.
Documents privileged under s.123; no production without permission.

precedents_cited.relevance: Privilege for court of enquiry report on public policy grounds.

precedents_cited.case_name: Smith v. The East India Company
precedents_cited.relevance: Privilege for official correspondence even commercial.
Majority: head decides injury; minority: Court inspects.

precedents_cited.case_name: Governor-General in Council v. H. Peer Mohd. Khuda Bux Ors.
Robinson v. State of South Australia
precedents_cited.relevance: Court inspects if affidavit vague; but no s.162 equivalent.

precedents_cited.case_name: Duncan v. Cammell Laird Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Minister's objection conclusive; class or contents.

precedents_cited.case_name: Khawaja Nazir Ahmad v. The Crown
precedents_cited.relevance: Court no power to examine; dissented from.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Privilege for state documents; Court decides validity of objection.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Cabinet advice secret; supervisory jurisdiction; appeal certificate.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed. Supreme Court held Punjab High Court erred in directing production of four documents; they relate to affairs of State (cabinet minutes and PSC report), privileged under s.123; head decides production. Affidavits sufficient.

key_quotes.text: "No one shall be permitted to give any evidence derived from unpublished official records relating to any affairs of State, except with the permission of the officer at the head of the department concerned."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.123 verbatim, foundation of privilege.

key_quotes.text: "The Court is competent, and indeed is bound, to hold a preliminary enquiry and determine the validity of the objections to its production, and that necessarily involves an enquiry into the question as to whether the evidence relates to an affair of State under s.123 or not."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "public interest must override considerations of private good and private interest."
key_quotes.speaker: court
